docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Elian Returns to Cuba After Justices Decline Case Elian Gonzalez returned to Cuba with his father and other family members aboard a chartered jet, hours after the Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal brought by Miami relatives who wanted an asylum hearing for the boy. A1 Sadness and anger pervaded the crowd that gathered outside the house in Little Havana, in Miami, where Elian was taken shortly after being found at sea in an inner tube in November and where he lived during most of the custody battle. A14 Russia Unveils Economic Plan The Kremlin issued its long-awaited plan to overhaul Russia's economy. It would slash subsidies that have held down utility rates, devise a new energy policy and wipe out unpaid wages, tax breaks and other obligations that sap government spending power. The announcement almost overshadowed another major event: a vote in Parliament's upper house against President Vladimir V. Putin's plan to effectively disband it. A6 U.S. and Russian Missile Plan Russia and the United States will hold a joint defense exercise against short- and medium-range missiles, an American official said. A7 Delay Urged on Missile Defense A group of more than 40 China scholars and former diplomats want President Clinton to delay a decision on building a national missile defense, saying it may do more harm than good to American interests. A9 Iraqi Storms U.N. Office An Iraqi man brandishing two machine guns and explosives shot his way into a United Nations office in Baghdad, Iraq, killing 2 people, wounding 7 and taking about 50 hostage. After a siege of nearly three hours, he gave himself up, saying he wanted an end to United Nations sanctions against his country. A3 Two Iranian Reformers Jailed Iranian officials sent a student leader and a human rights lawyer to jail without trial. At the same time, the national police commander held responsible in an attack on student protesters last year was fired. A5 Mideast Meeting in Doubt The Israelis and Palestinians appeared to remain far from meeting the conditions set down by the Clinton administration for an early summit meeting in Washington. A3 World Briefing A6 NATIONAL A18-28 Court Rules Governments Can't Ban Type of Abortion The Supreme Court, ruling 5 to 4 in a Nebraska case, said the government cannot bar doctors from using a procedure widely known as ''partial-birth abortion,'' because it may be the most medically appropriate way of terminating some pregnancies. A1 Boy Scouts Can Bar Gays The Supreme Court, ruling 5 to 4 in a New Jersey case, said the Boy Scouts may exclude gay members because opposition to homosexuality is part of their ''expressive message.'' A1 House Endorses Drug Benefit The House passed a bill offering prescription benefits to 39 million elderly and disabled people on Medicare, but only after Democrats walked off the floor to express frustration at being unable to get a full debate on a proposal to establish more extensive drug coverage. A1 Campaign Finance Legislation The House overwhelmingly passed bipartisan legislation to require tax-exempt groups that raise and spend money on political advocacy to disclose their activities and donors. A21 Defending Gore on Fund-Raising President Clinton, in a wide-ranging news conference, defended Vice President Al Gore against accusations of campaign finance irregularities, saying that Mr. Gore had made ''a compelling case'' that he did nothing wrong. A21 No Pass for Reagan Attacker A Washington psychiatric hospital withdrew its recommendation that a court let John W. Hinckley Jr. leave the hospital for unsupervised weekly visits with his parents. A18 California Official Steps Down Chuck Quackenbush resigned as insurance commissioner rather than risk impeachment over accusations that he diverted millions in earthquake insurance settlements. A18 EDUCATION Parochial School Aid Allowed The Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 3, that a federal program that puts computers and other ''instructional equipment'' in parochial school classrooms does not violate the separation between church and state. A27 NEW YORK/REGION B1-10 Effort on Police Corruption Is Inefficient, Panel Says A commission appointed by Mayor Giuliani to monitor the Police Department's anti-corruption efforts has found the internal system for disciplining officers staffed with inexperienced lawyers and mired in delays, according to a draft report. A1 Fallout From Power Failure Mayor Giuliani, responding to an East Side power failure on Monday, accused Con Edison of shoddy management and said he was reinstating an investigatory panel to review the utility's service to consumers. The city's top lawyer withdrew a settlement offer arising from last year's Washington Heights blackout. B1 Transforming Yellow Cab Fleet The Taxi and Limousine Commission will hold a hearing on a proposal to require new yellow cabs bought after July 1, 2001, to be wheelchair accessible, meaning they would mostly be tall sport-utility vehicles. B1 SCIENCE/HEALTH Deadly Toll of Diseases Infectious diseases worldwide claim far more lives than natural disasters, the Red Cross reported. A17 CIRCUITS G1-16 SPORTS D1-8 Nets Take Cincinnati Star The Nets, who had the first pick in the N.B.A. draft, used it to choose Kenyon Martin, a 6-foot-9 center-forward. The L.S.U. forward Stromile Swift went second, chosen by the Vancouver Grizzlies. D1 Sisters Win at Wimbledon Serena Williams beat Yvette Basting, 6-1, 6-0, and Venus Williams defeated Ai Sugiyama, 6-1, 6-4. The top-seeded Pete Sampras overcame Karol Kucera, 7-6 (9), 6-3, 3-6, 6-4. D4 OBITUARIES A29 Larry Kelley The Yale end who won the Heisman Trophy in 1936, which he sold at auction six months ago for $328,100, was 85. He died of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound. A29 BUSINESS DAY C1-24 Credit Card Settlement Providian Financial, a credit card issuer, agreed to a demand from bank regulators to reimburse customers at least $300 million for misleading and improperly billing them. A1 No Change in Interest Rates The Fed left interest rates unchanged, but warned that it could raise them again as soon as its next meeting, on Aug. 22, if it believed the economy was not slowing enough to avoid an upturn in inflation. C1 Major stock indexes were higher. C11 Oracle Defends Its Spying Lawrence J. Ellison, the chairman and founder of Oracle, defended his company's spying operation against Microsoft as a ''civic duty'' similar to investigative reporting. C1 Business Digest C1 HOUSE & HOME F1-20 ARTS E1-12 Lackluster Summer Box Office The summer movie season, which got off to a big start with ''Mission: Impossible 2,'' is no match for last year's box office performance. E1 EDITORIAL A30-31 Editorials: The court exits, in controversy; an end to secret campaign funds; Elian goes home. Columns: Bob Herbert. Bridge E10 TV Listings E12 Crossword E9 Weather B9 Public Lives B2

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We keep hearing about anticipated federal budget surpluses (front page, June 27). And we are facing a coming disaster: failure of our present health care system. Some hospitals are going bankrupt. Some insurers can't make money in the present environment. Health care providers are being asked to deliver less care to more people. It is almost impossible for a doctor to start a new practice. Millions of citizens do not have access to health care.
docs.abstract: Dr David P McClary letter, commenting on June 27 article on projected budget surpluses, says now it time to upgrade national health care system, which is on brink of disaster
